awd_titl_txt: Microcredentialing for the Unmanned Aerial Systems Workforce
awd_abstract_narration:
Unmanned aerial systems, sometimes referred to as drone technologies, are becoming a major economic sector nationally and worldwide. A highly-skilled, diverse workforce is needed to support this emerging sector. To meet this need, Mohawk Valley Community College will develop an educational model using microcredentials.  These microcredentials will document mastery of specific knowledge and skills related to the unmanned aerial systems industry, and "stack" to enable flexible training pathways. This strategy has the potential to help students develop initial competencies, while motivating them to persist toward a certificate or degree. The project will develop curricula for one-semester microcredentials, two-year degrees, and adapt these materials to support noncredit education in technician fields. Close collaborations with the local unmanned aerial systems industry cluster will help ensure that the curriculum meets industry needs. The project team will also work with the industry partners to develop hands-on lab and field exercises, and to foster student internship opportunities. The curriculum and materials developed in this project will be openly available for adaptation or replication at other institutions. The project has the potential to create resources that support education of the unmanned aerial systems workforce across the nation.

The project will aim to develop curriculum for six microcredentials; develop curriculum for two new associate degrees; refine the existing associate degree to align with categories of the microcredentials; and leverage these materials to support courses in unmanned aerial systems applications for emergency services, inspection, and agriculture. The curriculum will focus on preparing students to manufacture and repair unmanned aerial systems as well as analyze data collected on missions. The new associate degrees will be offered in Unmanned Aerial Systems Fabrication and in Unmanned Aerial Systems Electronics. In the new program structure, the microcredentials will be transferable between the degree tracks and accumulation of four microcredentials will be sufficient for students to earn the relevant associate degree. Project-based learning will be integrated through hands-on, industry-relevant student capstone and other projects. The courses will be designed to serve as pathways for current workers toward microcredentials or employment in the unmanned aerial systems sector. The project will conduct extensive outreach and recruitment of underrepresented populations to increase diversity in this technician field. The effectiveness of using microcredentials to address specific workforce skills and gaps will also be evaluated to determine if it can rapidly produce a skilled and diverse technical workforce. The results of the project will be broadly disseminated to assist other colleges in replicating and adapting the use of microcredentials for the unmanned aerial systems sector as well as other high-technology academic and workforce sectors.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Microcredentialing for the Unmanned Aerial Systems Workforce project at Mohawk Valley Community College achieved excellent results in developing and implementing new curricular models for technical workforce development in the field of remotely piloted aircraft systems. The project was designed to develop and refine curriculum, test the delivery of alternative credentialing options, and blend hands-on field projects with classroom instruction to produce experienced, capable technicians with a high skill level.

 

The project developed and leveraged outstanding industry connections with a wide range of employers in the unmanned aerial systems (UAS) field. These employer collaborators advised on field competencies needed in the workplace, served as experiential learning partners, and have hired program graduates. The project intentionally developed relationships with employers from a representative range of industries requiring unmanned aerial systems technicians, with participation from employers in public safety, agriculture, research & development, defense, and other sectors. These employers’ involvement created the framework for long-term, sustained industry involvement in program development as emerging technologies continue to transform the unmanned aerial systems workplace needs.

 

Further, the project assembled and coordinated a formal advisory board of industry stakeholders and employers to provide technical guidance for curricular development and credentialing models; based on this specialized consulting, the College pivoted the project model to develop three short-term, for-credit microcredentials in skill areas highly in demand within the UAS field; design an entry-level non-credit training for end users; and complete a major redevelopment of curriculum for the College’s signature drone program, an associate in applied science in Remotely Piloted Aircraft Systems. These activities successfully transformed the College’s UAS programming from a single lecture-based degree option to a broadly dynamic portfolio of technical credentials revolving around a projects-based, workforce-focused training model approved by local industry stakeholders.

 

Although the final year of project activities was delayed by state-mandated shutdowns associated with the COVID-19 pandemic, early project results demonstrate strong indicators of success. Despite the ongoing effects of the pandemic on enrollment and curricular delivery, 41 microcredentials were awarded within one-year of rollout for these alternative certifications, formalizing the skill attainment of students in competency areas including Data Analysis, Maintenance, and Operations. Degree enrollment in year 3 of the project increased 25% over the baseline year. While the aggregate number of students in the unmanned aerial systems program remains small, the achievement of an enrollment increase is notable in a time when the overall student population at the College has decreased due to the pandemic’s nationwide impact on community college enrollment.

 

In addition to employer satisfaction with the rigorous nature of the curricula, students have shown high levels of engagement and ability to grow their skills through the program. Student surveys produced consistently high ratings in relevance of coursework, increase of skill levels, and preparation for the workforce. The project-based nature of the curriculum tested in this project was a significant factor in achieving high levels of student engagement, and industry connections were cited as a key strength of the program.

 

Further, the project made great gains in developing a long-term workforce pipeline in STEM fields. The project developed/deployed a series of intro-level workshops, summer programs, youth competitions, and other interventions delivered in multiple formats and venues for hundreds of youth. These activities successfully increased youth awareness of STEM and UAS opportunities, while also boosting their entry-level skills and preparedness to enter the field. These pipeline developments led to a groundbreaking partnership with three local school districts to launch an accelerated pathway to UAS credentials for high school youth. The new seamless recruitment & enrollment model opens up enormous potential for rapid, sustainable growth of the UAS technical workforce.

 

Dissemination of project results is ongoing; awareness has been generated through participation on a future of work podcast, presentation of a paper at a conference, and extensive media recognition though print, web, social platforms, and the featuring of the college program on three episodes of an internet-based unmanned aerial systems reality show. Broader impacts are already being seen as other programs at the College begin to incorporate microcredentialing and employer advisory boards into curricular frameworks; to date, seven other STEM programs at the College have launched their own microcredentials, building on the success and lessons learned in this project.

 

As a model for development of the technical workforce, the Microcredentialing for the Unmanned Aerial Systems Workforce project at Mohawk Valley Community College has made outstanding progress in designing a new model in close collaboration with industry partners, testing that model for multiple student cohorts, and deploying a finalized curriculum for rapid technician development in high-demand skill areas. In addition to the broader impacts this project achieves through the testing/launch of a new technical training model, the project has also developed an extremely promising enrollment model in partnership with local school districts, effectively addressing the long-term sustainability of the technical workforce.  

 


Last Modified: 10/05/2021
Modified by: Timothy Thomas
